index.html.title: Welcome to ScratchVerifier
paragraphs: Verify Scratch accounts as genuine, for use in authorization or identification.

index.html.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: You've found the documentation for ScratchVerifier's API! These pages show you how to use ScratchVerifier for anything you might be making that needs to know who somebody is on Scratch.
This documentation is on GitHub so feel free to submit an issue for any corrections or improvements!

index.html.heading: Bugs
paragraphs: If you find something that you think is a bug, report it on GitHub and we'll be sure to check it out.

index.html.heading: Getting Started
paragraphs: See the usage walkthrough to get started!

reference.html.title: API Reference
paragraphs: The ScratchVerifier API is a HTTP/REST API for all operations.
API Base URL: http://scratchverifier.ddns.net

reference.html.heading: Authorization
paragraphs: Authorization is done using Basic HTTP Authorization, using your client ID as the username and token as the password.

reference.html.heading: API Endpoints
paragraphs: The simplicity of this API is such that there are only two total endpoints for its ultimate purpose.

http.400 Bad Request: username is invalid by Scratch rules

reference.html.heading: API Usage Endpoints
paragraphs: These endpoints fetch API usage logs.

limit=n.desc: Return at most n logs. n cannot be greater than 500

start=n.desc: Return logs that happened before (not including) the log with ID n. Usually used for getting the next page of logs. This does not have to be a valid ID (though it usually is)

before=n.desc: Return logs that happened before (and including) the Unix epoch time n

end=n.desc: Return logs that happened after (not including) the log with ID n

after=n.desc: Return logs that happened after (and including) the Unix epoch time n. Usually used to limit returned logs by time

client_id=n.desc: Only return logs with the client ID n

username=name.desc: Only return logs with the username name

type=n.desc: Only return logs with the log type n

log ID.desc: ID of log entry to fetch

reference.html.heading: Objects
paragraphs: Various endpoints have defined return types. They are documented below.

reference.html.name: Verification
reference.html.desc: Holds data related to verifying a user on Scratch.

reference.html.name: Session
reference.html.desc: Holds the session ID to use in other API registration endpoints.

reference.html.name: User
reference.html.desc: Holds data that a client needs to access the API.

reference.html.name: Log
reference.html.desc: Holds log data for a verification.

client_id.desc: client ID responsible for this log

reference.html.heading: Log Types
paragraphs: Logs can have three types:

items: 1: verification started
2: verification succeeded
3: verification failed

usage.html.title: ScratchVerifier Usage
paragraphs: This page contains a walkthrough for using this API.

usage.html.heading: Basic Walkthrough
paragraphs: The API root URL is http://scratchverifier.ddns.net
After registering, here's how to use this API:

items: Send an HTTP PUT request to /verify/{username} with the client ID and token you obtained as HTTP Basic authorization
The API will send you a Verification object containing a code
Have your client post that verification code on their own profile comments
Send an HTTP POST request to /verify/{username}
If your client is verified, you should receive a 204 No Content response. Done!

registration.html.title: ScratchVerifier Registration
paragraphs: This page contains walkthroughs for registering/handling your registration with this API.

registration.html.heading: Registering Through the Website
paragraphs: This is how to register with this API through the website.

items: Visit the website.
Click "Login/Register" at the top right
You will be presented with a verification code. (That's right, we use our own API to register people with it!)
Post this code on your own profile comments
Click "Continue"
You will then be logged in
You will be presented with a button saying "Create client". Click it
You will be shown your client ID and a button to copy your token.
Put your client ID and token into your app's configuration. Done!

paragraphs: At any point, if you wish to view your info again, simply login (if necessary) and you will be presented with it.

registration.html.heading: Registering Through the API
paragraphs: The API itself provides endpoints to register yourself. Here's how to use them:

items: Send an HTTP POST request to /users/{yourusername}/login
The API will send you a Verification object containing a code
Post this code on your own profile comments
Send an HTTP POST request to /users/{yourusername}/finish-login
You will receive a Session object containing a single integer. This is your session ID; it lasts for a year
Assuming you haven't already created a client, send an HTTP PUT request to /session/{session}
You will receive a User object containing your client ID and token
Put your client ID and token into your app's configuration. Done!

paragraphs: At any point, if it becomes necessary to fetch your info again, simply send an HTTP GET request to /session/{session} and you will receive it. If you receive a 401 Unauthorized response, you need to get another session ID by following steps 1-5.

registration.html.heading: Resetting your Token
paragraphs: If you think your token has been compromised, you can reset your token using the website:

items: Visit the website. If presented with your current info, skip to step 8
Click "Login/Register" at the top right
You will be presented with a verification code
Post this code on your own profile comments
Click "Continue"
You will then be logged in
You will be presented with your client info
Click the button labelled "Reset token"
Copy your new token and update your app's configuration. Done!

paragraphs: Or using the API:

items: GET /session/{session} to fetch your info
If you receive your info, skip to step 8. Otherwise, continue with step 3
Send an HTTP POST request to /users/{yourusername}/login
The API will send you a Verification object containing a code
Post this code on your own profile comments
Send an HTTP POST request to /users/{yourusername}/finish-login
You will receive a Session object containing a single integer. This is your session ID; it lasts for a year
Send an HTTP PATCH request to /session/{session}
You will receive a new User object containing your client ID and updated token
Update your token in your app's configuration. Done!

registration.html.heading: Deleting your Account
paragraphs: We're sorry to see you go! You can deregister from the API through the website:

items: Visit the website. If presented with your current info, skip to step 8
Click "Login/Register" at the top right
You will be presented with a verification code
Post this code on your own profile comments
Click "Continue"
You will then be logged in
You will be presented with your client info
Click the button labelled "Delete Account"
Click the confirmation. :(

paragraphs: Or using the API:

items: GET /session/{session} to fetch your info
If you receive your info, skip to step 8. Otherwise, continue with step 3
Send an HTTP POST request to /users/{yourusername}/login
The API will send you a Verification object containing a code
Post this code on your own profile comments
Send an HTTP POST request to /users/{yourusername}/finish-login
You will receive a Session object containing a single integer. This is your session ID; it lasts for a year
Send an HTTP DELETE request to /session/{session}
You will receive a 204 No Content response. :(

paragraphs: Note: This only deregisters your client from the API. You are still free to re-register later. Resetting your token is almost like deregistering and re-registering again.
